questions.question: When did the UK become fully democratic?
questions.explanation: The UK has been fully democratic since 1928, when all adults gained the right to vote.

questions.question: At what age can people vote in the UK?
questions.explanation: The voting age of 18 was set in 1969.

questions.question: Who can vote in UK public elections?
choices: UK, Commonwealth, and Irish citizens living in the UK
questions.explanation: UK, Irish, and Commonwealth citizens resident in the UK can vote in all public elections.

questions.question: What must you be on to vote in an election?
questions.explanation: You must be on the electoral register to vote in parliamentary or local elections.

questions.question: How can you register to vote?
choices: By registering online or by paper form
questions.explanation: You can register online or by downloading and submitting a paper form.

questions.question: When does the annual canvass take place?
questions.explanation: The annual canvass starts in July each year.

questions.question: What must you do if you change your name, address, or nationality?
choices: Register again on the electoral register
questions.explanation: You must register again on the electoral register if these details change.

questions.question: Where can the public view the electoral register?
choices: At electoral registration offices or libraries
questions.explanation: The register is available at local registration offices and some public buildings like libraries.

questions.question: What are polling places called in Scotland?
questions.explanation: In Scotland, polling stations are called polling places.

questions.question: What are the polling station opening hours on election day?
questions.explanation: Polling stations open from 7:00 am until 10:00 pm.

questions.question: What must you show at a polling station?
questions.explanation: You must show photo ID before voting.

questions.question: How can you vote if you cannot go to a polling station?
questions.explanation: You can register for a postal vote to vote from home.

questions.question: Who can stand for public office in the UK?
choices: UK, Irish, and Commonwealth citizens aged 18 or over
questions.explanation: UK, Irish, and Commonwealth citizens aged 18 or over can stand for office.

questions.question: Who cannot stand for public office?
choices: Civil servants, armed forces, and those convicted of certain crimes
questions.explanation: Members of the armed forces, civil servants, and those guilty of certain offences cannot stand.

questions.question: Can members of the House of Lords stand for the House of Commons?
questions.explanation: Members of the House of Lords cannot stand for election to the House of Commons.

questions.question: Where can the public watch debates in Parliament?
choices: In the public galleries of both Houses
questions.explanation: You can watch debates from public galleries in the House of Commons and the House of Lords.

questions.question: Is entry to Parliament debates free?
questions.explanation: Entrance to the public galleries is free.

questions.question: Where does the Northern Ireland Assembly meet?
questions.explanation: The Northern Ireland Assembly meets at Stormont in Belfast.

questions.question: Where does the Scottish Parliament meet?
questions.explanation: The Scottish Parliament meets in Holyrood, Edinburgh.

questions.question: What is the name of the Welsh Parliament building?
questions.explanation: Members of the Welsh Parliament meet in the Senedd building in Cardiff Bay.
